tickets.summary: GOTS-Critical-152190: Google Chrome < 92.0.4515.131 Multiple Vulnerabilities
tickets.description: Synopsis A web browser installed on the remote macOS host is affected by multiple vulnerabilities. Description The version of Google Chrome installed on the remote macOS host is prior to 92.0.4515.131. It is, therefore, affected by multiple vulnerabilities as referenced in the 2021_08_the-stable-channel-has-been-updated-to advisory. Note that Nessus has not tested for this issue but has instead relied only on the application's self-reported version number. Solution Upgrade to Google Chrome version 92.0.4515.131 or later. See Also http://www.nessus.org/u?06a1804d https://crbug.com/1227777 https://crbug.com/1229298 https://crbug.com/1209469 https://crbug.com/1209616 https://crbug.com/1218468 https://crbug.com/1214481 https://crbug.com/1232617

tickets.summary: CLONE - DTS Endpoints - 179692 - Node.js 16.x < 16.20.2 / 18.x < 18.17.1 / 20.x < 20.5.1 Multiple Vulnerabilities (Wednesday August 09 2023 Security Releases).
tickets.description: Finding Description: The version of Node.js installed on the remote host is prior to 16.20.2, 18.17.1, 20.5.1. It is, therefore, affected by multiple vulnerabilities as referenced in the Wednesday August 09 2023 Security Releases advisory: Permissions policies can be bypassed via Module._load (CVE-2023-32002) Permission model bypass by specifying a path traversal sequence in a Buffer (CVE-2023-32004) process.binding() can bypass the permission model through path traversal (CVE-2023-32558) Permissions policies can impersonate other modules in using module.constructor.createRequire() (CVE-2023-32006) Permissions policies can be bypassed via process.binding (CVE-2023-32559) fs.statfs can retrive stats from files restricted by the Permission Model (CVE-2023-32005) fs.mkdtemp() and fs.mkdtempSync() are missing getValidatedPath() checks (CVE-2023-32003) Note that Nessus has not tested for these issues but has instead relied only on the application's self-reported version numbe Solution: Upgrade to Node.js version 16.20.22 / 18.17.1 / 20.5.1 or later. CVE: CVE-2023-32002, CVE-2023-32003, CVE-2023-32004, CVE-2023-32005, CVE-2023-32006, CVE-2023-32558, CVE-2023-32559

content.text: The version of Node.js installed on the remote host is prior to 16.20.2, 18.17.1, 20.5.1. It is, therefore, affected by multiple vulnerabilities as referenced in the Wednesday August 09 2023 Security Releases advisory:
Permissions policies can be bypassed via Module._load (CVE-2023-32002)
Permission model bypass by specifying a path traversal sequence in a Buffer (CVE-2023-32004)
process.binding() can bypass the permission model through path traversal (CVE-2023-32558)
Permissions policies can impersonate other modules in using module.constructor.createRequire() (CVE-2023-32006)
Permissions policies can be bypassed via process.binding (CVE-2023-32559)
fs.statfs can retrive stats from files restricted by the Permission Model (CVE-2023-32005)
fs.mkdtemp() and fs.mkdtempSync() are missing getValidatedPath() checks (CVE-2023-32003)
Note that Nessus has not tested for these issues but has instead relied only on the application's self-reported version numbe
Upgrade to Node.js version 16.20.22 / 18.17.1 / 20.5.1 or later.

#!/bin/bash
plist="/Library/Managed Preferences/com.apple.SoftwareUpdate.plist"
delay=$(defaults read "$plist" MajorOSManagedDeferredInstallDelay 2>/dev/null)
forced=$(defaults read "$plist" forceDelayedMajorSoftwareUpdates 2>/dev/null)
if [[ -n "$delay" && -n "$forced" && "$forced" -eq 1 ]]; then
    echo "<result>MajorOSDeferred: ${delay} days</result>"
else
    echo "<result>No Major Deferral or Not Forced</result>"
fi

still on macOS 13. These devices have been identified as unable to receive automated OS upgrades due to issues related to their FileVault encryption state. Automated update processes (including

if attempted via automation) typically require specific FileVault conditions (e.g., being fully encrypted and unlocked by an authorized user, or specific handling for FileVault states during upgrade).

Confirm SecureToken status of the user who will be enabling FileVault.
Escrow a recovery key to Jamf Pro if manual enablement is performed.
Diagnose network connectivity issues (DNS, firewall, proxy, general network health).

tickets.summary: CLONE - DTS Endpoints - 234350 - pgAdmin < 9.2 Multiple Vulnerabilities
tickets.description: Finding Description: The version of pgAdmin installed on the remote host is prior to 9.2. It is, therefore, affected by the following vulnerabilities: Remote Code Execution security vulnerability in pgAdmin 4 (Query Tool and Cloud Deployment modules). The     vulnerability is associated with the 2 POST endpoints; /sqleditor/query_tool/download, where the     query_commited parameter and /cloud/deploy endpoint, where the high_availability parameter is unsafely     passed to the Python eval() function, allowing arbitrary code execution. (CVE-2025-2945) pgAdmin <= 9.1 is affected by a security vulnerability with Cross-Site Scripting(XSS). If attackers execute     any arbitrary HTML/JavaScript in a user's browser through query result rendering, then HTML/JavaScript     runs on the browser. (CVE-2025-2946) Note that Nessus has not tested for these issues but has instead relied only on the application's self-reported version number. Solution: Upgrade pgAdmin to a version later than 9.2. CVE: CVE-2025-2945, CVE-2025-2946

tickets.summary: [macos] jamf self service+ testing and deployment
tickets.description: Title:  Test and Deploy Jamf Self Service+ for Upcoming Jamf Pro Update Description: Jamf has announced that Self Service+ will be a required component in future versions of Jamf Pro. To ensure a smooth transition and avoid any disruption when we update Jamf, we need to: Test Jamf Self Service+ in our environment for compatibility and user experience Identify and resolve any issues or conflicts with our current workflows Deploy Self Service+ to all managed devices prior to the Jamf Pro update This work is necessary to maintain compliance with Jamf’s requirements and to ensure our users continue to have access to self-service tools after the update. Please prioritize testing and deployment so we’re ready ahead of the Jamf Pro release.

items.toString:
*Title:* Test and Deploy Jamf Self Service+ for Upcoming Jamf Pro Update



*Description:*Jamf has announced that Self Service+ will be a required component in future versions of Jamf Pro. To ensure a smooth transition and avoid any disruption when we update Jamf, we need to:

* Test Jamf Self Service+ in our environment for compatibility and user experience
* Identify and resolve any issues or conflicts with our current workflows
* Deploy Self Service+ to all managed devices prior to the Jamf Pro update

This work is necessary to maintain compliance with Jamf’s requirements and to ensure our users continue to have access to self-service tools after the update. Please prioritize testing and deployment so we’re ready ahead of the Jamf Pro release.

tickets.summary: Implement Automated Change Log System for CPE Team Deployments
tickets.description:
The CPE team needs an automated change log system to track and communicate platform changes (such as VPN updates, configuration profiles, and patch deployments) without relying on manual documentation. The system should integrate with our existing tools (Jira, Slack, Confluence) to eliminate human error in reporting changes and provide consistent, informative summaries to stakeholders. Goals Eliminate manual documentation errors ("I forgot to post here") Provide automated, standardized change summaries Include critical context: what changed, why it was needed, and any important notes Integrate with existing tools (Jira, Slack, Confluence) User Story As a CPE team member, I want changes to be automatically logged and communicated so that stakeholders are consistently informed about infrastructure updates without relying on manual processes. Example Change Format WHAT: Deployed new version of Global Protect VPN client
WHY: Addresses critical security vulnerability CVE-2023-XXXX
NOTES: Users may need to restart their systems after the update
 Acceptance Criteria System automatically detects CPE platform changes Change information is captured in a standardized format Change logs are published to designated Slack channels Change information is recorded in Confluence Related Jira tickets are automatically updated Stakeholders receive consistent, informative summaries

{noformat}

# Change logs are published to designated Slack channels
# Change information is recorded in Confluence
# Related Jira tickets are automatically updated
# Stakeholders receive consistent, informative summaries

h2. What We're Building

AI-powered Mac support platform that instantly analyzes computer health, security compliance, and provides troubleshooting guidance through Jamf integration.

*Current Problem:* Technicians spend 30+ minutes manually gathering computer info from Jamf for each ticket.  
*Our Solution:* Enter serial number → get complete analysis in 10 seconds.

h2. Work To Complete

h3. *Phase 1: Polish & Core Features (2-3 weeks)*

* [ ] UI/UX improvements and professional styling
* [ ] Jamf API optimization with error handling  
* [ ] Enhanced security audit dashboard (5-point compliance check)
* [ ] Export functionality (PDF reports, CSV data)
* [ ] Performance optimization and caching
* [ ] Knowledge base auto-loading from local files

h3. *Phase 2: Advanced Features (4-6 weeks)*

* [ ] Bulk computer analysis (multi-serial input)
* [ ] ServiceNow integration (ticket pre-population)
* [ ] Recovery key secure display with copy function
* [ ] Advanced AI responses with knowledge base context
* [ ] Usage analytics and ROI tracking
* [ ] PDF knowledge base text extraction

h3. *Phase 3: Enterprise Ready (8-12 weeks)*

* [ ] SSO authentication and role-based access
* [ ] Audit logging and compliance reporting  
* [ ] Multi-tenant support for departments
* [ ] Advanced dashboards and fleet analytics
* [ ] Production deployment and monitoring

h2. Expected Results

h3. *Immediate Impact (Phase 1)*

* *60% faster* ticket resolution (30 mins → 10 mins info gathering)
* *Standardized* security compliance checking
* *Professional reports* for ticket documentation
* *Ready for upper management demo*

h3. *Full Platform Impact (Phase 3)*

* *$130K annual savings* in technician productivity
* *95% automated* security compliance coverage
* *100% technician adoption* within 30 days
* *Enterprise-grade* platform ready for organization-wide deployment

h2. Success Criteria

✅ Sub-10 second computer analysis response time  
✅ 5-point security audit with actionable recommendations  
✅ Export capabilities for all analysis data  
✅ 99.5% uptime during business hours  
✅ Positive user feedback from pilot technician group

----

*Dependencies:* Jamf Pro API access, Google Gemini API, cloud hosting  
*Timeline:* 12-16 weeks total, deployable increments every 2-3 weeks  
*Team:* 1-2 developers, part-time PM/stakeholder management

tickets.summary: Phase 1: Secure BYOD Rollout
tickets.description: As part of our new Mobile Device Security Standard, we have completed the MDM Proof of Concept (POC). This epic covers all tasks required to  roll out and finalize  the secure Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program for employee-owned mobile devices, ensuring alignment with stricter compliance regimes and security best practices. Context We concluded the MDM POC, comparing Jamf, Intune, and Google MDM solutions. We validated basic security controls (central login, data containerization, offboarding processes). We now need to finalize Phase 1 (BYOD) by  publishing the Mobile Device Security Standard , confirming enforcement configurations, and completing any remaining policy or technical tasks before the broader rollout.

items.toString:
As part of our new Mobile Device Security Standard, we have completed the MDM Proof of Concept (POC). This epic covers all tasks required to *roll out and finalize* the secure Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program for employee-owned mobile devices, ensuring alignment with stricter compliance regimes and security best practices.

*Context*

* We concluded the MDM POC, comparing Jamf, Intune, and Google MDM solutions.
* We validated basic security controls (central login, data containerization, offboarding processes).
* We now need to finalize Phase 1 (BYOD) by *publishing the Mobile Device Security Standard*, confirming enforcement configurations, and completing any remaining policy or technical tasks before the broader rollout.

By detecting these outliers, we can optimize our license usage. Goals: Detect Duplicates:  Identify any devices or users consuming more than one license, possibly due to configuration issues, device re-enrollments, or user account duplications. Automate License removal:  Build github action that runs weekly or monthly to remove license

tickets.summary: [PRD] Enhancing Security and Change Management for Jamf
tickets.description: Problem Statement: The current process for managing scripts within Jamf lacks robust security measures and change tracking, which poses risks for unauthorized modifications and potential vulnerabilities. Without a formalized approach to logging, alerting, and change requests, we are unable to effectively monitor script changes or ensure that all modifications are reviewed for security implications. Proposed Improvement: This epic aims to establish a comprehensive framework for managing Jamf scripts that enhances security and accountability. By integrating logging into our SIEM, implementing alerts for admin actions, and developing a structured change request process, we will improve oversight and traceability of script modifications. Additionally, forking the script repository to our internal GitHub will ensure that all changes are reviewed for security issues before deployment. This initiative will not only mitigate risks associated with unauthorized changes but also foster a culture of security and diligence in our development practices. Key Action items Log Management: Collaborate with the DE team to integrate logs from this and all Jamf-managed scripts into our SIEM. Alert Creation: Work with DE to establish alerts for admin actions where applicable. Configuration Monitoring: Coordinate with DE and Platform Engineering to assess if Cortex can detect modifications to the  onlofflschedule  configuration by end users. Change Request (CR) Process: Develop a CR process to track changes made to the script and identify responsible parties. Repository Management: Fork the OSS repo to our internal GitHub for script management. Ensure all changes are reviewed for security issues via GHAS before merging. Access Control: Implement a formal request and CR process for Jamf access. Testing Protocol: Conduct testing of new script versions on a small subset of machines before full deployment.
